intro: Hymenoxys metcalfei, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a herbaceous plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of numerous small florets. The plant features showy yellow to orange ray flowers surrounding a central disk of tubular flowers, which attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It typically grows in dry, rocky soils and thrives in full sun, making it a hardy and drought-tolerant species. Hymenoxys metcalfei is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to bloom throughout the growing season.
